Introduction

Viscerosomatic reflexes are physiologic interactions in which visceral dysfunction or irritation leads to somatic (ie, musculoskeletal) manifestations.  This form of somatic dysfunction is often perceived as pain, muscle tension, and/or tissue texture changes.  Viscerosomatic reflexes were particularly important before modern diagnostic techniques (eg, CT scans, ECGs) because physical examination findings could serve as key indicators pointing to underlying visceral pathology.  Although these reflexes are still clinically relevant in osteopathic medicine for understanding somatic contributions and demonstrating potential supportive signs, their role in diagnosing occult visceral disease is less critical today due to advanced diagnostics.

Pathophysiology

Underlying mechanisms



A viscerosomatic reflex occurs when afferent (sensory) signals from visceral irritation travel via autonomic pathways to the spinal cord and synapse on the dorsal horn.  These signals can influence nearby somatic neurons, particularly those innervating skin, muscle, and connective tissue.  A major contributing factor is facilitation, a state of sustained subthreshold excitation of spinal interneurons that leads to exaggerated motor and sympathetic nervous system hyperactivity.  Facilitation via the spinal reflex occurs as follows:



  • Sensory (afferent) input:  Injury to a visceral structure activates mechanoreceptors and nociceptors.
  • Spinal pathway:  Continued afferent input from the injured tissue sensitizes interneurons in the spinal cord.  These interneurons mediate communication between afferent and efferent pathways and become more easily activated over time.
  • Motor (efferent) output:  Once interneurons are sensitized, a lower-than-normal threshold of sensory input is sufficient to trigger somatic motor neuron firing.


Increased sympathetic activity at a given spinal level contributes to the development of viscerosomatic reflexes that often manifest as paravertebral muscle hypertonicity and/or somatic dysfunction at corresponding vertebral levels.

  • T1-T4:  Head and neck.
  • T1-T5:  Heart.
  • T2-T7:  Lungs.
  • T2-T8:  Esophagus.
  • T5-T9 (via the greater splanchnic nerve and celiac ganglion):  Upper gastrointestinal (GI) tract, including the stomach, proximal duodenum, spleen, liver, and gallbladder.
  • T10-T11 (via the lesser splanchnic nerve and superior mesenteric ganglion):  Middle GI tract, including the distal duodenum, jejunum, ileum, ascending colon, proximal two-thirds of the transverse colon, kidneys/adrenals, upper ureters, and gonads.
  • T11-L2 (via the least splanchnic nerve and inferior mesenteric ganglion):  Lower GI tract, including the distal third of the transverse colon, descending/sigmoid colon, rectum, uterus/cervix, prostate, lower ureters, and bladder.

Chapman points



Another manifestation of a viscerosomatic reflex is the formation of Chapman points (ie, 2- to 3-mm, tender neurolymphatic gangliform contractions) associated with an irritated organ; for example, Chapman points in cardiac ischemia may be palpable near the sternocostal junctions of the second and third ribs (anteriorly (

Osteopathic manipulative treatment techniques



Treatment always prioritizes appropriate medical or surgical management of the underlying visceral condition (eg, antibiotics for infection, surgery for acute cholecystitis).  Osteopathic manipulative treatment (OMT) may be considered as an adjunctive therapy to relieve associated musculoskeletal dysfunction.  The techniques of choice aim to reduce sympathetic tone and enhance parasympathetic tone.  These techniques are typically forms of soft tissue or myofascial treatment and include:



  • Rib raising:  To perform this technique, the physician gently lifts the posterior rib angles along the thoracic spine with the patient supine.  Stretching the costovertebral areas where the sympathetic chain ganglia lie, rib raising helps reduce sympathetic nervous system firing and improves rib cage mobility.  Common indications include postoperative ileus and pneumonia.
  • Paraspinal inhibition:  This technique is closely related to rib raising and is applied in areas without ribs (eg, lumbar region) or in patients who cannot be easily positioned for rib raising.  Steady pressure is applied to the paravertebral muscles, producing a similar downregulation of sympathetic tone.  This technique is frequently used for postoperative pain and muscular hypertonicity in hospitalized patients.
  • Visceral ganglion release:  Palpatory pressure can be applied to the prevertebral ganglia in the abdominal region to "release" or inhibit the ganglia, reducing sympathetic outflow to the corresponding digestive organs.  These organ regions include the foregut (celiac ganglion), midgut (superior mesenteric ganglion), and hindgut (inferior mesenteric ganglion).  Indications include chronic abdominal pain and irritable bowel syndrome.
  • Sacral rocking:  The sacrum is a key anatomic influence on the parasympathetic supply to the lower GI tract because the pelvic splanchnic nerves (S2 through S4) emerge from the sacral region to innervate the descending colon and pelvic organs.  To perform sacral rocking, the physician gently applies an oscillatory pressure to the sacrum in synchrony with breathing.  This rhythmic motion can stimulate or normalize parasympathetic activity from S2 through S4, thereby helping regulate bowel and bladder function.  Indications include constipation and bladder dysfunction.
  • Sacral inhibition:  Similar to sacral rocking, the physician applies steady, sustained pressure directly to the sacrum, typically with the patient prone.  This gentle pressure reduces excessive parasympathetic tone and relieves conditions associated with heightened pelvic autonomic activity, such as dysmenorrhea and lower pelvic dysfunctions (eg, prostatitis).

Clinical examples



This section provides specific clinical examples of viscerosomatic reflexes.

Acute coronary ischemia



  • Visceral dysfunction:  Ischemia/infarction of myocardial tissue.
  • Viscerosomatic reflex pathway:  Afferent signals travel via cardiac sympathetic nerves (T1-T5 spinal levels).
  • Somatic manifestations:
    • Hypertonicity and tenderness in paraspinal muscles between T1 and T5.
    • Referred pain in the left shoulder/arm, interscapular pain (T2-T5 dermatomes).
    • Palpable tissue texture changes (eg, warmth, edema) over the upper thoracic spine.
    • Chapman points:  Tender nodules palpable anteriorly near the second and third ribs at the sternocostal junction, and posteriorly near the T2 spinous/transverse processes.
  • OMT application:  Once acute cardiac care is initiated (eg, percutaneous intervention), rib raising (T1-T5 spinal levels) can be applied to reduce excessive sympathetic drive contributing to pain and muscle spasm.

Cholecystitis



  • Visceral dysfunction:  Inflammation of the gallbladder (often due to gallstones).
  • Viscerosomatic reflex pathway:  Afferent signals travel via the greater splanchnic nerve (T5-T9 spinal levels, primarily T6-T9).
  • Somatic manifestations:
    • Hypertonicity and tenderness in right-sided paraspinal muscles T6 through T9.
    • Referred pain in the right subscapular region.
    • Palpable tissue texture changes over the right lower thoracic spine.
    • Chapman points:  Tender nodules palpable anteriorly in the intercostal space between ribs 5 and 7.
  • OMT application:  Alongside antibiotics/surgery, paraspinal inhibition (right T6 through T9) can help reduce sympathetic hyperactivity and associated muscle guarding/pain.  In addition, visceral ganglion release targeting the celiac ganglion can be considered.

Appendicitis



  • Visceral dysfunction:  Inflammation of the appendix.
  • Viscerosomatic reflex pathway:  Afferent signals travel via the lesser splanchnic nerve (T10-T11 spinal levels).
  • Somatic manifestations:
    • Hypertonicity and tenderness in right-sided paraspinal muscles T10-T11/L1.
    • Cutaneous hyperesthesia (increased sensitivity) in the dermatomes around T10-T11 (umbilical region).
    • Tissue texture changes over the right thoracolumbar junction.
    • Chapman points:  Tender nodules palpable anteriorly on the tip of the right 12th rib.
    • OMT application:  Although surgery is the definitive treatment, paraspinal inhibition (right T10-L1) can be used before or after surgery to help modulate pain and reduce muscle guarding related to the reflex arc.

Summary



Viscerosomatic reflexes represent connections between visceral pathology and somatic dysfunction, facilitating diagnosis and guiding therapeutic interventions in osteopathic medicine.  These reflexes arise due to the facilitation of spinal interneurons by persistent visceral afferent signals, manifesting clinically through characteristic somatic findings.  Chapman points are specific somatic indicators of visceral irritation, whereas targeted osteopathic manipulative treatment techniques aim to normalize autonomic balance, addressing both somatic symptoms and underlying visceral dysfunction.  Key techniques include rib raising/paraspinal inhibition, visceral ganglion release, and sacral rocking/inhibition.
